feed.title: Category: picks | User group for Viennese rubyists

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
02/24 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-third edition:

Ramón:
  • Youtube: The Game Boy, a hardware autopsy - Part 1: the CPU - The first in a series of videos explaining how the original Game Boy works.
  • Gem: Bourbon, Neat, and Bitters - A modular, SASS-based alternative to Bootstrap.
  • accounting.js - A lightweight JavaScript framework for formatting currency values.
Markus:
  • Understand TDD by asking one simple question - Pat Maddox manages to boil down the basics of TDD into a simple question.
  • Simple 8-bit Assembler Simulator - A complete simulation of a simple 8-bit assembler written in JavaScript, including visualizations of the CPU and memory. Great for exploring how a program actually works on a near-machine level.
  • Towards an understanding of technical debt - “Technical debt” is an overloaded and messy term. Kellan Elliott-McCrea attempts to clear up some of the confusion and fuzzy definitions.
Gerald:
  • Using Markdown with the kramdown Library and Tools - by Thomas Leitner (author of kramdown from - surprise, surprise - Vienna); slides (in HTML)
  • Vienna Opens World’s 1st Dr. Jekyll Walk-in Clinic - any question or trouble with static sites? Ask Dr. Jekyll and get free advice and in-person answers at the next meetup.
  • Static Blogging Tool Face-Off: Middleman vs Jekyll - by David Turnbull published on SitePoint (Nov/2015)
  • GitLab Pages - powered by - surprise, surprise - Middleman ;-)

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
02/17 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-third edition:

Laura:
  • Gutenberg - A web typography starter kit
  • Templates on GitHub - GitHub have recently introduced Issue and Pull Request templates on their blog!
  • Git Kraken - There’s a new Git GUI in town.
Markus:
  • So You Want to Use Pathnames… - If you’re working with paths or filenames in Ruby, Piotr Szotkowski shows why using the Pathname class is so much nicer than just using plain Strings.
  • Kill Your Dependencies - Dependency bloat afflicts all languages. In Ruby, it’s especially easy to have your dependencies explode. Mike Perham shares some tips on reducing your own dependencies.
  • TIL: clock skew exists - Martin Kleppmann recently wrote a critique of the Redlock distributed locking algorithm. Amongst his criticisms was that clocks can very easily become skewed. Julia Evans investigates this phenomenon a bit more, and what exactly can happen to a clock on a computer.
Tawan:
  • Fish shell design documentation - I recently switched from zsh to fish shell, and so far I’m quite happy with it. If you haven’t already, you should definitely take a look and try it out. I picked the design documentation of Fish shell, because it’s a good read and it resonates a lot with the experience I had so far.
Max:
  • How to prepare and write a tech conference talk - Absolute guide to conference talks by Lena Reinhard.
  • Scientist: Measure Twice, Cut Over Once - Insights on how Github rewrites parts of their system.
  • Coolors - Preferred way to find, choose or compare colorschemes (use your spacebar!).
Gerald:
  • Boom! Jekyll Starter Theme - static site starter theme for books using boom! - a microformat for books
  • Gutenberg Jekyll Starter Theme - another static site starter theme for classic books using gutenberg - a web typography starter kit
  • Free Jekyll Book (Beta) - (Official) Jekyll docu reformatted as a single-page online book in black ‘n’ white

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
02/10 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-third edition:

Laura:
  • Frankly - A dashboard of issues and PRs for GitHub repos, made by the amazing Monica <3
  • Designing an editor theme for developers - Cat Noone explains in this article the process and conscious design decisions she went through when designing her Toothpaste editor theme. A really cool read!
  • Toothpaste - A theme for Sublime Text designed with the user in mind. It’s even F.lux-friendly!
Ramón:
  • Ruby’s “unless X” is processed differently than “if !X”! - Syed Humza Shah goes into some interesting intricacies of how Ruby handles boolean logic.
  • Jekyll Polyglot - I was making a multi-language Jekyll page, and found this very helpful for i18n!
Markus:
  • NASA’s 10 rules for developing safety-critical code - The software that runs anything that goes into space is very critical, regardless of humans being aboard or not. These rules help NASA write software that’s unlikely to fail even if your robot is currently exploring the outer fringes of our solar system.
  • When back doors go bad: Mind your Ps and Qs - Jeffrey Goldberg of 1Password explains how elliptic curve cryptography works, and why crypto that allows for backdoors (even if there aren’t any) is generally less secure that crypto that doesn’t allow backdoors in the first place.
  • The “Cobra Effect” that is disabling paste on password fields - Troy Hunt tells the story of how the British tried to get a handle on their cobra problem in India, how it spectacularly backfired, and how this relates to modern-day snake-oil security measures.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
02/03 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-third edition:

Laura:
  • Lektor - From Carinthia with love: a new static CMS created by Armin Ronacher
  • Getting started in Open Source - A list of articles, tutorials and resources
Markus:
  • The Two Hard Things
  • Improve your PostgreSQL workflow with vim and dbext - You got psql in my Vim.
  • Why don’t schools teach debugging? - It’s a fundamental skill, but there are no classes for it.
Gerald:
  • Stay Static Showcase - Inspired by TodoMVC Showcase; Same Sample Site Built w/ Jekyll, Middleman (Yes!), Hugo and others
  • Static Times - We live in static times! Follow along - the latest news (incl. static site spotlights) about Jekyll, Middleman and friends
  • Vienna.html 2nd Meetup - Tu Feb/23rd - Join us @ sektor5. Free. Everyone welcome. Short talks about Building Page Layouts with Susy Grid by Bernhard Benke; Using Markdown (HTML “Shortcodes” in Plain Vanilla Text) with the kramdown Library and Tools by Thomas Leitner and (much) more
  • GitHub Pages now faster and simpler with Jekyll 3.0 - Yay!

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
01/27 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-third edition:

Laura:
  • TrumpScript - It’s not Ruby but it’s still too great not to share.
  • Lotus is now Hanami - Lotus has recently been renamed; read all about it in this blog post.
Ramón:
  • Nativefier - Run web apps as if they were native! Runs on Electron.
  • RubyMotion: MotionKit - Really helpful DSL for setting up view layouts. No need for Interface Builder files!
  • Influencing Web Layouts with Print Layouts - I found this an interesting read on using more magazine-styled layouts.
Markus:
  • On Ergonomics - Why an ergonomic working place is important (unless you like constant pain)
  • Conceptual Debt is Worse than Technical Debt - Yes, there’s something even worse than technical debt out there.
  • How to trick a neural network into thinking a panda is a vulture - Neural networks can do amazing things, but they can be tricked into seeing things that aren’t quite what they seem.
Max:
  • The Bike Shed 48: “Is Everyone Trying Their Best?” - Software is broken - Derek and Sean on why it’s not fun to be one of the developers who just don’t care.
  • Switching from rbenv to postmodern’s ruby-install and chruby - Remind the unix philosophy and ditch rbenv (or rvm) for something more lightweight.
